title: The Song of Moses
shortSummary: Deuteronomy 32 records the Song of Moses, a poetic declaration of God's faithfulness contrasted with Israel's rebellion. It serves as both a reminder of God's righteous character and a prophetic warning of judgment and restoration. This chapter underscores the covenant relationship between God and His people, highlighting divine justice and mercy.
timeline: c. 1406 BC - Final days of Moses before entering the Promised Land

keyCharacters.name: Moses
keyCharacters.description: The servant of the LORD who delivers this prophetic song to Israel, summarizing their history and God's dealings with them.

keyCharacters.name: Jeshurun
keyCharacters.description: A poetic name for Israel used here to represent the nation’s favored status and subsequent rebellion.

keyCharacters.name: Hoshea (Joshua) son of Nun
keyCharacters.description: Moses’ assistant who hears the song alongside the people, preparing to lead Israel into the Promised Land.

definitions.definition: A poetic name for Israel meaning 'upright one,' used affectionately to describe the nation.
A metaphor for God’s strength, stability, and faithfulness.
God’s righteous judgment and recompense against sin and rebellion.
The land and blessings God promised to Israel as His chosen people.

outline.heading: Introduction and Call to Hear
outline.description: Moses calls heaven and earth to witness as he declares the perfection of God's works and Israel’s corruption, highlighting the folly of forsaking their Creator.

outline.heading: God’s Faithfulness to Israel
outline.description: A recounting of God’s care and provision for Israel, illustrating His guidance and protection as a loving Father.

outline.heading: Israel’s Rebellion and Idolatry
outline.description: The nation’s unfaithfulness is exposed as they turn to foreign gods, provoking God’s jealousy and anger.

outline.heading: Judgment Announced
outline.description: God declares the consequences of Israel’s rebellion, including calamity and judgment, but also promises ultimate vindication and mercy.

outline.heading: Moses’ Final Exhortation and God’s Command
outline.description: Moses charges Israel to obey God’s law and records God’s instruction for Moses’ final journey and death.

application: Recognize God’s perfect character and faithfulness as the foundation for trusting Him in all circumstances.
Avoid spiritual complacency by remembering the dangers of turning away from God to idols or worldly influences.
Embrace God’s discipline as a loving correction that leads to repentance and restoration.
Commit to teaching God’s Word diligently to the next generation as Moses commanded.

keyVerses.text: He is the Rock, his work is perfect: for all his ways are judgment: a God of truth and without iniquity, just and right is he.
keyVerses.significance: This verse affirms God's unchanging perfection and justice, foundational truths for faith and trust.

keyVerses.text: But Jeshurun waxed fat, and kicked: thou art waxen fat, thou art grown thick, thou art covered with fatness; then he forsook God which made him, and lightly esteemed the Rock of his salvation.
keyVerses.significance: It warns against spiritual pride and neglect of God, showing the consequences of turning away from Him.

keyVerses.text: See now that I, even I, am he, and there is no god with me: I kill, and I make alive; I wound, and I heal: neither is there any that can deliver out of my hand.
keyVerses.significance: God declares His sovereignty over life and death, emphasizing His unique power and authority.

keyVerses.text: For it is not a vain thing for you; because it is your life: and through this thing ye shall prolong your days in the land, whither ye go over Jordan to possess it.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the life-giving power of obedience to God's Word.
